For example, it does not accept gay marriage, abortion, and birth control. These are not old-fashioned views, but they are not open to new ideas. People are leaving the Church because they do not agree with these views. The Church is against abortion, so people who support it may not feel comfortable. People who want to marry someone of the same gender may also feel this way. I do not see why the Church cannot have female priests or allow priests to be married. But I am not sure if these changes would have prevented the problems the Church is facing. The Church says priests are married to God, but other people have families and jobs too. So, priests should also have a family life, I think.

In fashion, men might be seen as less serious if they are straight.

Gender discrimination exists in other industries too.

I do not believe it is right for a state or the government to make it legal. I think the decision should be up to the churches. The Constitution states that the government should not interfere with religious beliefs.

I think many people believe this issue should be decided by the churches, not the government. Most Catholics and Christians do not support it. In Boston and other areas, there are some who do, but I do not think it is the government's place to decide what religions can and cannot do.

Separation of church and state is very important in our country. It allows for religious tolerance. Adding an amendment to change this would be wrong and go against what is already written in the Constitution. Plus, it would be one of the few amendments that restrict people, not the government.

I do not think the federal government or any government should be involved in this issue. If someone wants to push for an amendment, it should be because of their personal beliefs, not to restrict people's choices.

I believe it is up to the churches to decide about this issue, not the president or any other government official. There is no good reason to add an amendment to the Constitution to make it illegal. In fact, it might have a positive effect on society.

I think I have said all that I need to say.

I am for gay marriage. I always have been.
I think it is a personal choice. It is not something people can control.
I think it is unfair to take away people's rights because of something they cannot change.
I believe in giving people the freedom to be who they are.
I do not think politics and government should decide about personal relationships.
I know people in my neighborhood who are gay. They live their lives just like everyone else.
I think it is wrong for leaders to say what marriage means.
I think marriage should be a private matter, not a public one.

I have heard that being gay might be a result of biology, not just society.
I do not believe that marriage should be different for gay people.
I think if a man and a woman want to marry, they can do it quietly.
But if two gay people want to marry, it becomes a big news story.
I think marriage should be a personal matter, not a public one.

I do not think it is fair for the government to decide about marriage.
I think people should be able to marry whoever they love.

I will not put harmful things on the internet. For example, I will not talk about blowing things up or shootings. If I say such things, people will think badly of me. It is important to be careful about what I do on the internet and to be responsible for my actions.

Yes, I feel that gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States.
It affects not only women but also men in certain jobs.
For example, in business, some people have difficulty working with a woman boss.
Even when a woman has all the qualifications, some people may not consider promoting her.
Likewise, men who stay at home to raise children can face discrimination.
Society often expects men to be the primary breadwinner.
In fashion, men might be seen as less serious if they are straight.
This is because they may not understand women's fashion as well as women.
Gender discrimination exists in other industries too.
For example, in farming, people might not take someone seriously if they have poor grammar.
This can happen even if they are very intelligent.
Change happens slowly, and pushing too hard can cause people to resist.
We have made progress, but it takes time.
People are starting to accept women in higher positions and men as stay-at-home parents more.
We should promote good qualities of people who are discriminated against.
We should do this without forcing change too quickly.
We should also consider that people might discriminate against each other based on their job or background.
For example, someone from a farm might face discrimination if they have poor grammar.
Men might look down on them if they think they are not intelligent.
So, discrimination happens in many ways.

I think that two people in a union should not be questioned about the type of marriage they have.

People who want to marry someone of the same gender may also feel this way. I do not see why the Church cannot have female priests or allow priests to be married. But I am not sure if these changes would have prevented the problems the Church is facing. The Church says priests are married to God, but other people have families and jobs too. So, priests should also have a family life, I think.

I think our church has changed to fit the 21st century. It is not as strict now. When I was younger, I would go to church every Sunday. I would wear cute dresses, matching shoes, and a purse. But now, they have a teen mass that is just 30 minutes long. People dress more casually, especially in the summer. Sometimes, families arrive late and wear beach clothes. Even in the morning masses, people wear jeans and khakis. I don't know much about church politics, but this is the biggest change I have noticed. But I don't think they always knew. I have no other thoughts about the Catholic Church.

Yes, I feel that gender discrimination is still a problem in the United States.

For example, in business, some people have difficulty working with a woman boss.
Even when a woman has all the qualifications, some people may not consider promoting her.
Likewise, men who stay at home to raise children can face discrimination.
Society often expects men to be the primary breadwinner.
In fashion, men might be seen as less serious if they are straight.
This is because they may not understand women's fashion as well as women.
Gender discrimination exists in other industries too.
For example, in farming, people might not take someone seriously if they have poor grammar.
This can happen even if they are very intelligent.
Change happens slowly, and pushing too hard can cause people to resist.
We have made progress, but it takes time.
People are starting to accept women in higher positions and men as stay-at-home parents more.
We should promote good qualities of people who are discriminated against.
We should do this without forcing change too quickly.
We should also consider that people might discriminate against each other based on their job or background.
For example, someone from a farm might face discrimination if they have poor grammar.

So, discrimination happens in many ways.

I think yes. Many things they do are very traditional, like long lasting customs. It's good to stay rooted in tradition. But it's also important to be flexible for change. Some Catholics go to church every week and are strict about how things are done. They might not accept others who don't follow the rules perfectly or who are from other religions. For example, my parents couldn't marry in the Catholic Church because my dad was an Episcopalian. This isn't very tolerant of other religions. We learned to love others, but it's hypocritical to not accept them. Some Catholic teachings say to do one thing, but the practice goes against it. It's outdated, but they still keep it. I think allowing priests to marry wouldn't stop child molestation. These things happen regardless of marriage status. So, I probably don't think that would be an issue.

I am not sure about this issue yet. I cannot say if one side is right or wrong. This topic is very difficult because it is close to the separation of church and state, and it is not easy to define marriage without hurting someone's feelings. I think all civil unions should be treated the same. If the government treats marriage as a sacrament, like baptism, then it should also consider civil unions the same way. People would not get tax breaks or be treated in a special way by the government if they were married by a church. So, I think marriage and civil unions should be treated the same. I think that two people in a union should not be questioned about the type of marriage they have.

If all states can agree on this, they should make it a federal law. But, I think a constitutional amendment to ban gay marriage is not reasonable. It is not important enough to change the constitution. Gay marriage is not a big enough issue to change the constitution. Simply put, no.

I was raised in a Christian family. Homosexuality is hard for me to understand because I have many gay friends. I do not agree with their lifestyle, but I think it should be legal. I believe each state should decide this, not the president.

Democratic states will likely support gay marriage. If you live in a democratic state, you should accept the state's decision. I think homosexuals should have the same rights as heterosexuals. Each state should decide if they want to legalize it.

I do not think President Bush should decide how the whole country feels about gay marriage. He is not the president of all states. He should not make decisions that affect states. I believe each state should decide on its own. The president is only in office for a few years. If a democratic president lifts the ban, it will just go back and forth. It is best to leave the decision to each state.

I do not support the president's ban on gay marriage.
